title: Layout
description: Layout defines how elements are arranged on a page. Good layout creates clarity, hierarchy, rhythm, and a sense of visual order. It helps users understand what matters, what's related, and where to look next.

content.text: Layout is the foundation of interface design. Even with perfect typography and colour, a poor layout can make a design feel confusing or overwhelming.

items: Creates visual hierarchy
Improves readability and scanning
Groups related content
Guides the user's eye
Supports accessibility and usability

content.text: Grids provide structure and consistency. They help align elements, create rhythm, and ensure your layout feels intentional rather than random.

items: Column grids — used for multi-column layouts
Modular grids — combine columns and rows
Baseline grids — align text across the page
Use consistent column widths and gutters
Align elements to the grid whenever possible
Use whitespace to break the grid intentionally

content.text: Visual hierarchy helps users understand what's important. It's created through size, spacing, colour, alignment, and placement.

items: Size — larger elements attract more attention
Position — top and left are seen first
Colour — high contrast draws the eye
Spacing — more space = more importance
Grouping — related items should be close together

content.text: Alignment creates order and reduces cognitive load. Misaligned elements make a design feel messy, even if everything else is perfect.

items: Left alignment — most readable for text
Center alignment — good for short content
Right alignment — used sparingly for emphasis
Pick one alignment and stick to it
Avoid mixing left and center alignment in the same block
Use alignment to create clean vertical lines

content.text: Whitespace (or negative space) is the empty space around elements. It's not wasted space — it's what makes content readable and interfaces breathable.

items: Improves readability
Creates separation between groups
Reduces visual noise
Helps users focus on what matters
Trying to fill every space
Inconsistent spacing between elements
Not enough space around text blocks

content.text: Many interfaces follow predictable layout patterns. These patterns help users understand your design quickly because they've seen them before.

items: Single column — simple, linear reading
Two column — content + sidebar
Card layouts — modular, scannable content
Grid galleries — visual content collections
F‑pattern — common for text‑heavy pages
Z‑pattern — common for landing pages
